title: 112_hr4352
content: The Act may be cited as the "Nation Building Here at Home Act of 2012" and includes a Transformational Infrastructure Competitive Grant Program. The "Nation Building Here at Home Act of 2012" establishes a transformational infrastructure competitive grant program to assist projects with significant impact on metropolitan areas, regions, or the United States. Grants can be awarded to state governments, local governments, transit agencies, and port authorities for eligible projects determined by the Secretary of Transportation. The "Nation Building Here at Home Act of 2012" establishes a competitive grant program for infrastructure projects with significant impact on metropolitan areas, regions, or the United States. Eligible projects include highway or bridge projects, public transportation projects, and passenger or freight rail transportation projects. The "Nation Building Here at Home Act of 2012" establishes a competitive grant program for infrastructure projects including rail transportation, port infrastructure, aviation infrastructure, and water infrastructure. Coordination is required for water infrastructure projects with the EPA and Army. Eligibility for grants is based on specific criteria. The Act establishes a grant program for infrastructure projects. Entities meeting specific criteria must submit an application to the Secretary. The Secretary will issue regulations for grant awards within 90 days, including criteria for financial commitments. The Act establishes a grant program for infrastructure projects. Entities meeting specific criteria must submit an application to the Secretary. The Secretary will issue regulations for grant awards within 90 days, including criteria for financial commitments from non-Federal sources. The Federal share of project costs may not exceed 100 percent. Grants should be distributed equitably, address urban and rural needs, promote veteran employment, and support small businesses. The Act requires grant recipients to ensure a percentage of funds go to small businesses owned by disadvantaged individuals. Projects must comply with Title 40 requirements and use American-made iron, steel, and goods, with exceptions for public interest cases. The Act mandates that grant recipients allocate funds to disadvantaged small businesses and use American-made iron, steel, and goods, with exceptions for cases where domestic production is insufficient or cost-prohibitive. Waivers require detailed justification and must align with international agreements. The Secretary must ensure grants are used efficiently, provide public information on grants, and report to Congress annually. $250 billion is authorized for the program in fiscal year 2013. $250 billion is authorized for the program in fiscal years 2013-2017. The Nation Building Here at Home Financing Initiative is authorized for $250 billion in fiscal years 2013-2017. The Secretary of the Treasury, in consultation with the Secretary of Transportation, will establish a Nation Building Here at Home Financing Initiative within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Treasury Secretary may issue bonds up to $300 billion with specified characteristics. Proceeds from these bonds will be made available to the Secretary of Transportation. The Secretary of Transportation can only use proceeds from bonds issued under subsection (b) to carry out the program established under section 2(a) of this Act. The Secretary of Transportation must submit a report to Congress within 180 days of the Act's enactment detailing the transportation needs of the United States for the next 20, 30, and 50 years.
